title: Welcome Visitors
synopsis: Welcome to this [[Federated Wiki]] site. From this page you can find who we are and what we do. New sites provide this information and then claim the site as their own. You will need your own site to participate.

title: How the Other Half Lives
synopsis: How the Other Half Lives: Studies among the Tenements of New York  was an 1890 work by pioneering photojournalist [[Jacob Riis]]. It documented the poverty of New York City's Lower East Side at the time. [http://www.bartleby.com/208/ bartleby]

title: Chinatown's Telegraph
synopsis: In [[How the Other Half Lives]] author Riis notes how a particular telegraph pole in New York's Chinatown was the heart of the community information system.

title: Data Journalism Pages
synopsis: A list of pages on data journalism.

title: Population Pyramid History
synopsis: The population pyramid chart was an American invention, invented in 1870s by [[Francis Amasa Walker]] and featured in his Statistical Atlas of the United States, the report published on the 1870 United States census. It is sometimes called a bilateral histogram.

title: Confounding Maleness
synopsis: One of the questions to ask of any analysis is how gender composition of the sample may have affected statistical results. A good example of this comes from 19th century misconceptions about Chinese immigrants.

title: Queen of the Endless Chain
synopsis: "Queen of the Endless Chain" is a 1908 article on Natalie Schenck, the teenager who, in 1898, overloaded a local U.S. post office by starting a chain letter to fund an ice plant for the Red Cross for soldiers in the Spanish-American War. She eventually raised the 1898 equivalent of a million dollars. [https://books.google.com/books?id=mHs4AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA525&dq=Natalie+Schenck+spanish+american&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YnidVcSoJ8_moATg27SoBg&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false books]

title: Natalie Schenck
synopsis: Natalie Schenck (1882-1929) was one of the more amazing women of her time. After a bizarrely successful fundraising effort as a teen, a failed marriage to a swindler, and the death of a second husband, she went on to success on Wall Street, becoming one of the first prominent women in Wall Street banking. [http://rsparlourtricks.blogspot.com/2005/12/woman-in-counting-house.html post]

title: Qualifications of the Woman Banker
synopsis: Name of an article printed in 1925 by the Brooklyn Eagle on the rise of Mrs. Natalie Schenck Laimbeer (nee Natalie Schenck) to a top spot in a Wall Street bank. It's a rather extraordinary article.

title: Charles Glenn Collins Affair
synopsis:
Collins defrauded  Princess Zoltylroff, alias Lady
Muriel Paget, alias Mrs. Margaret Prebble of vases.

title: Charles Glenn Collins
synopsis: Charles Glenn Collins was the model for Colonel Ayers in Faulkner's Mosquitoes
